explanation: Acceleration tells you how quickly speed is changing.
Force = mass × acceleration. More mass or more speed-up means more force.
Light moves faster than anything else—nothing beats it.
Friction slows things down when they rub together.
Weight is gravity acting on mass: more mass = more weight.
Density = mass divided by volume.
Floating happens because water pushes up on objects.
Sound is a wave that travels through matter like air or water.
Sometimes light acts like a wave, sometimes like a particle.
Electric current is moving charge, like electrons in a wire.
A capacitor stores energy by holding electric charge.
A magnet or a moving charge makes a magnetic field around it.
Changing magnetic fields can produce electricity.
SHM means something moves in a repeating cycle, like a spring.
Pressure = Force ÷ Area. Smaller areas = more pressure.
Objects stop speeding up when air drag matches gravity.
Light changes direction when it moves between materials.
Diffraction happens when waves go through gaps or around edges.
Waves can add up to make a bigger wave if they match.
Waves meeting out of sync can cancel each other.
Like gravity, electric fields can store energy in positions.
More power means energy is used faster.
Momentum = mass × velocity. Bigger or faster things have more.
Impulse is force × time, and it changes momentum.
Torque causes rotation and depends on how far the force is from the pivot.

More power means energy is used faster.
Momentum = mass × velocity. Bigger or faster things have more.
Impulse is force × time, and it changes momentum.
Torque causes rotation and depends on how far the force is from the pivot.
In a system with no outside forces, the total momentum stays the same, even if objects inside the system bounce off each other.
Kinetic energy is motion energy. If something is heavier or faster, it has more of it.
Gravity gives things energy when you lift them. The higher they are, the more energy they have.
Ohm’s Law says current increases if voltage goes up, assuming resistance stays the same.
Entropy is disorder. In a closed system, it always increases or stays the same.
When something falls with gravity and *only* gravity acting on it. So, no air resistance or engines.
Think throwing a ball. Horizontally it keeps going, vertically it rises then falls because of gravity.
This is the force that the ground uses to push up on you so you don’t fall through.
When a rope or string pulls on something, it creates tension. Everyone feels the same tension through the rope.
The more you stretch or squish a spring, the harder it pulls back. F = -kx.
Going in a circle? There must be a force pulling toward the center.
Even at constant speed, going in a circle means you're constantly accelerating—because your direction’s always changing.
For every action, there’s an equal and opposite reaction. You push on a wall—it pushes back.
If you do work on something, its energy changes. So pushing = more kinetic energy.
Energy can’t be created or destroyed—just changes form.
This is the sum of kinetic + potential energy. It stays constant if there’s no friction or external work.
Any two objects with mass attract each other. Even you and your phone.
Like charges repel, opposites attract. Comes in positive and negative.
This is how a charge 'reaches out' to affect other charges around it.
Think of it like electric pressure. Higher voltage = more push for charges to move.

Think of it like electric pressure. Higher voltage = more push for charges to move.
Current is the flow of electric charge. It's what powers devices.
This is what makes it harder for current to flow. Wires, resistors, even your body.
In series, everything is one path. In parallel, current can split.
For magnetism: fingers in current direction, curl them, thumb points in magnetic field direction.
Changing magnetic fields = electricity. That’s how generators work.
If a magnet moves near a coil, the coil gets current that fights the change.
The direction of induced current opposes the change that caused it.
They swing with constant back-and-forth motion, and their period depends on length—not mass!
These move energy without moving matter long distances. Think sound, water waves.
This is wave height—higher amplitude = more energy.
How often a wave cycles per second. High frequency = short wavelength.
The time for one full wave cycle. It’s the inverse of frequency.
That high-pitch siren sound coming toward you? Lower when it passes? That’s Doppler.
Waves trapped between boundaries create repeating patterns—like guitar strings or microwave hot spots.
